comments.value: Date is provisional (and pending approval of security arrangements by ITS).
Feb 1 is looking unlikely. We are planning to send a test feed over to e-Dialog this week, but it will be very surprising if the switchover can be concluded in January.

That’s fine – we are now expecting this to take longer than originally planned.

Aiming for 1 March now

Update: We have sent a large subset of the user database (via the secure feed mechanism) and are awaiting feedback from e-Dialog.

Assuming there are no major issues, we should be able to switch to a daily feed as soon as we hear back from e-Dialog.
J: So far I have spent ~8 days on this

So far we have spent :

- Jamie: ~1 day communication / investigation / calls etc.

Here's my assessment. Jamie, you might want to double-check & add/amend if necessary.

1. (TwoFour) supply the "player".
2. (TwoFour) import all of the existing videos from the site, create thumbs, titles, etc.

3. (LOCOG) Manual task: Edit all existing video pages (166 of them). For each one, you need to find the programmeId from TwoFour, and paste it into the Video page's metadata. This step, although it might seem cumbersome, means that we won't have any duplicates / omissions, and the switchover should then be silent/seamless.
So long as TwoFour are serving the video correctly, these pages can be launched on an ad-hoc basis.

4. (TwoFour) switch on the "notifier". This will "ping" the cms, telling it about each new/updated/deleted video. On the first run, it will notify the CMS of all current videos. This is a slightly redundant step but it will help with testing.
Moving forward, whenever a video is created/updated/deleted in TwoFour, the CMS will be notified, and a Video page will be created/updated/(published)/delated.

5. (LOCOG) Moving forward, Blog & News articles can link to a video by linking to it (from the metadata pane).

Jamie, see my list, below.

comments.value: Awaiting new site structure

Will need to look at rewriting urls at publication time (ie. pages have to have hrefs with contain the short form) and in reverse we need to display the page (via a InteralRedirect) when it is requested via the short url.

There a a couple of approaches I can think of, but this is not a Redirect issue (per sea), it's about making the website appear to have a different URL structure that it does in the CMS.

A possible (although to be approach with caution as it may be very limiting) is to actually change the site structure in the CMS. Although I prefer the approach of allowing some pages to have a 'publication path' which is the path that gets used in links/hrefs published out of the CMS and also in the opposite direction allows us to create a mapping back to the real location of the file (in the CMS or on the file system); this approach allows us to create a /schedule page now and have all links on the site use  /schedule but for the page to actually live somewhere other than the top level of the site for the moment.

From: Liz Goulding
Sent: 30 March 2011 10:39
To: Caroline Hadfield; Roli Barker
Subject: Email update

Hi both,

Here's the scoop:

1.       Budget:  They think it ought to be less than 2 days (£1400), but given that we often ask for lots of tweaks/changes, they are uncomfortable committing to less than that.  So what I propose is a two day cap on the work, but they will actually charge us by the hour ... which could work out to being less than 1 day.  That is how the New Media team work with them on a retainer, so they are very much trustworthy (and I'll watch them).  So if you can ringfence the £1400 for the next week until they complete work, and then raise a PO for the actual amount, hopefully everyone will be happy.

2.       Format: One way of keeping the budget down (it will be much easier for them) is a type of email where the logo comes in embedded as a 'linked image'.  To most users connected to the internet, the email will appear just as you've requested.  The only exception is that if someone downloads all their emails, then turns off their internet connection and tries to look at it, the image won't be there.  It's pretty unusual for people to do that - most people stay connected to the internet when reading their emails - but it is technically possible.  If you are ok with that, then I think we're much more likely to keep it to a day's work.

Let me know if you're happy and I'll get them started!

Liz

P.S.  They're working on the export and 2010 events - it should be fixed today/tomorrow.
